Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of East Greek, possibly Dorian, pottery cup with everted rim; interior glazed black; exterior: three bands on rim and a fourth at top of handle zone, plus accidental drip mark; in handle zone, part of set of verticals flanking the handle at left break and 8 vertical zig-zags central; wall below glazed save for a narrow reserved band; reserved area at base on body. Rim warped and surface much spalled on left side.
Curator's comments: The sherd was deformed and discoloured as a result of a fire. Two similar sherds (British Museum 1965,0930.972.a and 1965,0930.972.d) were analysed with NAA by H. Mommson (Bonn). The fabrics were determined to be of the same origin but the source of the fabric was not determined. Dupont and Thomas (2006, p. 80) analysed a similar sherd (sample number NAU 55), to which they attributed a Vroulian style. According to the analysis of the fabric of the sherd, the precise region in eastern Greece from which the vase originated is unknown but Dupont and Thomas discard both a Rhodian and Nile Delta production. They suggest that the sherd probably has a Dorian provenance and also point out that it is highly unlikely that sherds were over-fired during production but rather were damaged as a result of an intense fire. The sherd joins British Museum 1965,0930.972.a and possibly belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1965.9-30.972.e.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GM.25) (phase 3)
